data.meta_description: A cronological account of insurgent related and political incidents in Bhutan since 1952. This page is continuously updated.
data.text:
2000 January 10 Teknath Rizal says he may campaign for constitutional change unless the King grants him an audience. July 6 The Royal Government of Bhutan says the outlawed United Liberation Front of Assam (ULFA), a terrorist group who principle area of operation is India's Assam State, is transferring funds through its diplomatic baggage abroad. Two employees of the Foreign Ministry are sacked for connivance and legal proceedings are initiated against them. July 10 Immediately after Bhutan National Assembly's passed resolution calling for launching operations to drive out Indian terrorists from its territory, Assam Chief Minister Prafulla Kumar Mahanta proposes joint-military action against terrorists holed up in Bhutan's forests. September 14 Bhutanese refugee groups in Nepal welcome the European Parliament's call for their early repatriation to Bhutan. November 7-9 The Seventh Round Table Meeting (RTM) of development partners for Bhutan is held in Thimphu. Some of the donor nations and agencies make a statement on discrimination against Lhotshampas (meaning people of the south--a term used to refer to ethnic Nepalese who inhabit southern Bhutan) and on the refugee issue. December 20 and 21 Attacks on Bhutanese citizens by armed terrorists from Assam in multiple raids leave 14 dead and more than a dozen injured December 25 The Country is in a state of red alert following the attack on Bhutanese by terrorists. 2001 January 10 Richard Boucher, US State Department spokesman, says Nepal and Bhutan are moving to implement their recent agreement to resolve the longstanding problem of nearly 100,000 persons claiming refugee status from Bhutan who have been hosted by Nepal in refugee camps during the past decade. January 27 The driver of a vehicle is severely beaten by Royal Bhutan police for entertaining ULFA terrorists.

February 11

The people of Bhutan express their willingness to take up arms, if necessary, to evict United Liberation Front of Asom (ULFA) and National Democratic Front of Bodo (NDFB) terrorists from Bhutan.

February 15

Human Rights Watch, Lutheran World Federation, Women's Commission for Refugee Women, Children Refugees International and Bhutanese Refugee Support Group write to the governments of Bhutan and Nepal expressing concern about the plight of Bhutanese refugees.

March 26

A joint verification Team (JVT) of Nepal and Bhutan starts the verification process at the Khudunabari refugee camp.

March 27

Bhutan's Foreign, Minister Jigme Thinley says any refugees allowed back into his country from Nepal will be free to speak their own language, practise their own religion and wear their traditional dress.

April 15 Bhutan warns Assam terrorists and deploys more than 3,000 soldiers along its border with India.

April 16

Bhutan warns its people to be prepared for a conflict with Indian terrorist groups--that have set up camps along its thick forests in the southern border--and prepares its people for clash with the terrorists.

April 18-26 India and Bhutan during the week-long visit of Foreign Minister Jigme Thinley discuss working together to counter terrorism and combat religious fundamentalism, as well as take action at the appropriate time to deal with Bodo and ULFA militants. May 17 Kyoko Yonezu, a UNHCR official in-charge of South Asia, visits the Joint Verification Team (JVT) office and refugee camps in Jhapa, Nepal. August 20 Nepalese delegation led by Finance Minister Ram Sharan Mahat places, what it called, concrete proposals on the verification of Bhutanese refugees in Nepal and repatriation, at the 11th round of the Joint Ministerial-level Meeting, in Thimpu. Bhutan disagrees with many aspects of the proposal.
